titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Robert Louis Stevenson Collection
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 06:19

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Robert Louis Stevenson Collection consists of correspondence, writings, photographs, artwork, and other material documenting the life, work, and remembrance of Robert Louis Stevenson.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired through various gifts and purchases from 1947 to 2004.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 22: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Robert Louis Stevenson Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Robert Louis Stevenson Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Robert Louis Stevenson collection contains material by and related to Stevenson acquired by the library through various gifts and purchases from 1947 to 2004. This material was previously shelved with the Edwin J. Beinecke Collection of Robert Louis Stevenson, in some cases interfiled, and known informally as the library's "Stevenson collection." During reprocessing of the "Stevenson collection" in 2009, material was identified and separated by provenance so that all Stevenson and Stevenson-related material acquired by Edwin J. Beinecke resides in the Edwin J. Beincke Collection of Robert Louis Stevenson (GEN MSS 664) and all Stevenson and Stevenson-related material acquired through other sources resides in the Robert Louis Stevenson Collection (GEN MSS 684).

This collection includes material formerly classed as Uncat Ms Vault 110, Uncat Ms Vault 240, Uncat Ms Vault 241, Uncat Ms Vault 370, Uncat Ms Vault 388, Uncat Ms Vault 406, Uncat Ms Vault 423, Uncat Ms Vault 644, Uncat Ms Vault 649, Uncat Ms Vault 693, Uncat Ms Vault 698, Uncat Ms Vault 721, Uncat Ms Vault 722, Uncat Ms Vault 734, Uncat Ms Vault 735, Uncat Mss 105, Uncat Mss 236, and Uncat Mss 512. The collection also includes material formerly classed as Uncat Ms Vault File Stevenson and Ms Vault Stevenson Supplemental, the bulk of which is in the Edwin J. Beinecke Collection of Robert Louis Stevenson (GEN MSS 664), as well as several items (McKay numbers 474, 2622, 6062, 6106a, 7580, and 8404) described in George Leslie McKay's A Stevenson Library: Catalogue of a Collection of Writings by and about Robert Louis Stevenson .

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Microfilm for portions of the collection is available from Access Services.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also Edwin J. Beinecke Collection of Robert Louis Stevenson (GEN MSS 664).

bioghist.head: Robert Louis Stevenson (1850-1894)
bioghist.p: Robert Louis Stevenson was one of the most popular and prolific British writers of the late 19th century, the author of verse, novels, travel books, short stories, plays, and essays, including such titles as The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde and Treasure Island . There is considerable secondary literature on Stevenson, including book-length biographical studies, chronologies, and bibliographies. Summary information is available in the standard print and online biographical resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Robert Louis Stevenson Collection consists of correspondence, manuscript notes and drafts, photographs, original artwork, printed ephemera, memorabilia, and other material relating to Robert Louis Stevenson acquired by the library through various gifts and purchases from 1947 to 2004. The collection spans the years 1765 to 1983, with the bulk dating from 1852 to 1931.

The collection is housed in 22 boxes and arranged by provenance. The collection includes named gifts and purchases from Major General and Mrs. John Ramsey Pugh, Justin G. Turner, Charles Scribner's Sons, Francis Woolsey Bronson, Christie's New York and the Alta California Bookstore, as well as smaller gifts and purchases from other sources. Boxes 14-21 and 22 contain Oversize and Restricted Fragile material respectively.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. Major General and Mrs. John Ramsey Pugh Gift, 1854-1983. II. Justin G. Turner Gift, 1765-1923. III. Charles Scribner's Sons Gifts, 1892-1932. IV. F. W. Bronson Gift, 1914-1938. V. Alta California Bookstore Purchase, 1881-1966. VI. Christie's Purchase, 1873-1893. VII. Material From Other Sources, 1867-1977.

did.unittitle: Major General and Mrs. John Ramsey Pugh Gift

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gifts of Major General and Mrs. John Ramsey Pugh, 1983.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Writings, and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence in Series I consists of letters from Robert Louis Stevenson to others, mostly family, arranged alphabetically by recipient. Writings consists of work by Stevenson and features notes and autograph drafts for numerous poems, stories, essays, and other works. Other Material consists of items about or relating to Stevenson, including third-party letters, biographical notes, and photographs.

The Pugh gift includes inventories for two 1963 donations, with item descriptions, and most letters and manuscripts include transcriptions and vendor or auction folders, which provide provenance informance on previous ownership and dates of purchase (1914-1915).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Photographs and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Justin G. Turner Gift, consists of photographs of Robert Louis Stevenson and his parents and other material about and relating to Stevenson. Photographs include an album containing twelve photographs of Stevenson from his infancy to his call to the Scottish bar, circa 1875, and six dageurreotypes. Other Material includes manuscript and printed material about Stevenson and memorabilia, such as a lock of hair and a wooden chest.

arrangement.p: Arranged alpabetically by name of artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Charles Scribner's Sons Gift, consists of original artwork done for Scribner's editions of Stevenson's The Wrecker (1892) and A Child's Garden of Verses (1905 and 1931). The series features roughly 100 illustrations by Florence Edith Storer Stone for the 1931 edition of A Child's Garden of Verses .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Correspondence and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Alta California Bookstore Purchase, consists of correspondence and other material relating to Stevenson. In addition to a few letters from Robert Louis Stevenson to his mother, the correspondence features letters from Fanny Van de Grift Stevenson and Lloyd Osborne to Stevenson and others. Other Material also features manuscripts by Fanny and Lloyd Osborne.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Letters from Robert Louis Stevenson and Manuscripts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI, Christie's Purchase, consists of a small number of autograph letters and manuscripts by Robert Louis Stevenson. Correspondents include Alexander Black, James Cotton, Mary Mapes Dodge, and Philip Gilbert Hamerton. Manuscripts include manuscript pages for St. Ives , notes, and illustrations.

did.unittitle: "The Reformation and John Calvin," notes, holograph
St. Ives , pages 88 and 92, holograph, corrected
Stevenson's copy of Edmund Gosse's On Viol and Flute , printed version, with illustrations and annotations in Stevensonon's hand
Transcription of letter by John Knox in hand of Stevenson

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: Correspondence, Writings, Artwork and Objects, and Other Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII, Material From Other Sources, consists of single items and small groups of material acquired by gift or purchase from sources other than those identified in Series I through Series VI. Correspondence consists of letters from Robert Louis Stevenson and third-party letters. Writings includes numerous corrected manuscript drafts by Stevenson and scripts and scores for theatrical adaptations of Stevenson's Treasure Island . Artwork and Objects include a plaster representation of Stevenson by Henry Gamley, an album of thirty-one drawings by French artist Jean Hugo for a limited edition of An Inland Voyage (Stamford, CT: Overbrook Press, 1938), as well as a chair owned by Stevenson. Other Material, which includes a Stevenson passport and royalty statements, consists chiefly of printed materials relating to Stevenson.
